name: Acupuncture
summary: A traditional East Asian medical practice that inserts very fine needles at specific body points to modulate pain pathways, autonomic tone, and homeostatic mechanisms. Used for pain, anxiety, insomnia, headaches, and functional disorders.
description: Acupuncture is a component of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) that aims to restore physiological balance by stimulating defined points on the body (acupoints) with filiform needles. Modern research suggests effects on endogenous opioid release, serotonergic and noradrenergic pathways, local neuroimmune signaling, and autonomic regulation. Variants include manual acupuncture, electroacupuncture, auricular acupuncture, and acupressure. It is widely integrated into pain management and supportive care and has growing evidence for certain conditions, while other uses remain investigational.

metadata.invasiveness_level: Minimally invasive (skin penetration with fine needles)
metadata.training_required: Licensed acupuncturist or physician with accredited acupuncture training
metadata.regulatory_status: Licensed complementary/alternative therapy; scope and licensure vary by jurisdiction

primary_indications: Chronic musculoskeletal pain (e.g., low back pain, knee osteoarthritis, neck pain)
conditions_treated: Irritable bowel syndrome and functional dyspepsia (adjunctive)
off_label_uses: Smoking cessation and substance use support (auricular protocols; mixed evidence)
contraindications: Absolute: refusal of consent, areas of active infection at needle site
Relative: bleeding disorders or anticoagulation, pregnancy (avoid contraindicated points), pacemaker (for electroacupuncture), severe neutropenia
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe when performed by trained practitioners using sterile technique; adverse events are uncommon and usually mild.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate for chronic pain, knee OA, headache prophylaxis, and postoperative nausea; limited/mixed for many other indications.

items: Chronic low back pain, neck pain, shoulder pain

sections.text: From a biomedical perspective, acupuncture modulates peripheral and central nociceptive processing via A-delta and C-fiber stimulation, increases endogenous opioid peptides (e.g., endorphins, enkephalins), engages descending inhibitory pathways (serotonin, norepinephrine), and influences limbic/autonomic networks (HRV improvements). Locally, it impacts neuroimmune signaling and microcirculation. In TCM theory, acupuncture regulates Qi and blood by harmonizing meridians and organ systems to restore homeostasis.

sections.preparation: Clinical evaluation and goal setting; identification of target patterns (TCM) or myofascial/segmental targets (medical acupuncture); informed consent; positioning and skin antisepsis.
procedure: Insertion of sterile, single-use filiform needles at individualized acupoints (commonly 6–20 points/session).
Manual stimulation or electroacupuncture applied for 10–30 minutes as indicated.
Needles retained typically for 20–40 minutes; reassess symptoms and adverse effects post-session.
sections.frequency: 1–2 sessions per week initially; adjust based on response.
sections.duration: 4–8 weeks for an initial course; maintenance or booster sessions as needed.
sections.total_treatment_time: Varies by condition; many chronic pain protocols use 6–12 sessions.

items: Electroacupuncture for neuropathic pain and knee OA
Auricular acupuncture for nausea, analgesia support, and SUD protocols (e.g., NADA; mixed evidence)
Acupressure/self-care for nausea, headache, and stress
Moxibustion for cold patterns and breech presentation (obstetric use requires specialist training)

immediate: Relaxation, reduced muscle tension, transient analgesia
short_term: Improved pain scores, sleep, and stress within 2–4 weeks
long_term: Sustained pain/function gains with periodic maintenance in responders

uncommon: Worsening of symptoms for 24–48 hours (usually self-limited)
rare: Pneumothorax with inappropriate chest wall needling

absolute: Active skin infection at intended needle sites
relative: Anticoagulation/bleeding diathesis (use superficial techniques, avoid deep needling)
Pregnancy: avoid strong stimulation and specific contraindicated points (e.g., LI4, SP6, BL60/67)
Pacemaker/implanted stimulators (avoid or take precautions with electroacupuncture)
special_considerations: Chest and upper back needling requires proper angle/depth to avoid pneumothorax.
Use pediatric-appropriate protocols and parental consent for children.

ideal_candidates: Individuals with chronic musculoskeletal pain seeking nonpharmacologic options
Patients preferring integrative care for headaches, insomnia, or anxiety
Oncology and perioperative patients for nausea/vomiting support
screening_required: Bleeding risk assessment and medication review
Infection/skin integrity check at planned sites

concurrent_therapies: Cognitive behavioral therapy for pain and insomnia
lifestyle_recommendations: Regular movement, sleep hygiene, and stress-reduction practices

sections.typical_session_cost: $60–$150 per session (varies by region and practitioner)
sections.total_treatment_cost: Initial course often 6–12 sessions; maintenance as needed
sections.insurance_coverage: Coverage varies; many plans cover for chronic low back pain and other indications

items: Evidence supports acupuncture over sham for chronic pain with small-to-moderate effect sizes; benefits may persist beyond treatment.
Electroacupuncture can enhance analgesic effects in some conditions.
Expectations and therapeutic alliance influence outcomes (context effects).
Use strict sterile technique; single-use needles are standard of care.

items.label: Vickers AJ et al. Acupuncture for chronic pain: individual patient data meta-analysis of RCTs. Arch Intern Med. 2012
NICE Guideline: Low back pain and sciatica in over 16s (recommends acupuncture selectively)
Lee SH, Lim SM. Acupuncture for postoperative nausea and vomiting: meta-analysis. Evid Based Complement Alternat Med. 2013
